Question: What is the methodology of this project?

Context: 

CCB & VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION:
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
The project activity includes AFOLU activities (project category ARR), which are supported by a
CDM methodology AR-ACM0003-Afforestation and reforestation project activities implemented
on lands other than wetlands (Version 02.0)24, approved under the VCS Program.
3.1.2 Applicability of Methodology
The project activity consists of plantation of multiple plants and tree species in the wasteland
and/or fallow agricultural land. The grouped project activity is in line with the eligibility conditions
of the AFOLU requirements as the project activity increase the carbon sequestration through the
planting of multiple plant and tree species; the project activity includes timber harvesting in their
management plan and the lands weren’t native ecosystems. As a grouped project activity, the
future plantations of the project will be in line with the eligibility requirements of the VCS. The
project activity does not intervene in native ecosystems. None of the sites are cleared of native
ecosystems within the 10-year period prior to the project start date for the purpose of creating
carbon credits. The project activity has included timber harvesting in their management plan.
It is demonstrated and justified how the project activity meets each of the applicability conditions
of the methodology AR-ACM003, Ver. 2.0.
Scope: This methodology excludes from its scope the land that falls into the category of wetland.
Criterion-1: The land subject to the project activity does not fall in wetland category.
As per the IPCC GPG LULUCF 2003, wetlands are defined as lands that are covered or
saturated by water for all or part of the year (e.g., peatland) and that does not fall into the forest
land, crop land, grass land or settlements categories including reservoirs, natural rivers and
lakes. The project activity sites consist of fallow agricultural land and wasteland does not cover
any wetlands. Hence, this criterion is applicable.
Criterion-2: Soil disturbance attributable to the project activity does not cover more than 10 per
cent of area in each of the following types of land, when these lands are included within the project
boundary:
(i) Land containing organic soils;
(ii) Land which, in the baseline, is subjected to land-use and management practices and receives
inputs listed in appendices 1 and 2 to this methodology.
Soil disturbance attributable to the project activity does not, in any case, cover more than 10% of
the total area. The land subjected to the project activity does not contain organic soil and there
were no land management practices carried out before the project.
Criterion-3: A project activity applying this methodology shall also comply with the applicability
conditions of the tools contained within the methodology and applied by the project activity.
(a) VCS tools & requirements:

1.14 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
Four types of forests were identified in the 7 municipalities, based on the Holdridge classification.
The types of forest found are:
• Tropical moist forest
• Very humid lower montane forest
• Very humid premontane forest and,
• tropical dry forest.
Based on the National Agricultural Census (2014), the total land use area of 1,623,117 hectares, of
which 67,968 hectares were destined for agricultural activities, 42,947 hectares were in permanent
crops, 18,966 hectares were in temporary crops, 6,056 were fallow and 25,021 were the combination
of transitional crops plus fallow.
For livestock activities there were some 1,406,041 hectares, of which 1,152,648 were exploited in
pastures and forage, 247,072 hectares in weeds and stubble, 3,298 hectares were savannah
vegetation, 3,023 hectares in xerophytic vegetation. Likewise, they had a total of 14,751 productive
units (National Agricultural Survey 2014)
o Geomorphology: The project area is characterized by alluvial-torrential deposits with
fluvioglacial or fluviovolcanic influence, covered by volcanic ash. Also, discontinuous colluvial-
alluvial deposits can be found as thin sandy-clayey alterites.
o Hydrology: The runoff in the area is 400 to 1000mm per year. Sedimentary and clastic volcano
environments are present with good hydrogeological possibilities.
o Climatology: It is located between 0 and 2,800 meters above sea level and is characterized
by the following elements: The temperature is between 12ºC. and 24°C., or more. The annual
precipitation is 1,500 to 3,000mm per year. The months of April to June and September to
November are the rainiest.
o Soils: The soils have a sandy-clay-loam texture, gravelly, grayish brown in color, granular
structure with moderately fine grains, rapid permeability, regular moisture retention, low
organic matter content, acidic pH 5.7, superficial soils, rock fragments, light to rapid erosion
and low fertility.
On the other hand, Indigenous communities in this region maintain traditional agricultural practices,
cultivating crops like maize, cassava, and potatoes. Traditional artisanal skills, such as weaving and
pottery, are important economic activities and cultural expressions.

3.1.2.1 Step 1. Forest management in the baseline scenario must be planned timber harvest
a. Legal Right to Harvest: The Ejidos, are considered the logging agent, and have a legal

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
was conceived as a grouped project, in order to be able to increase its contribution to the standing
forest with the addition of new instances of project activity in the future.
Beyond the project’s ecological and carbon benefits, a proportion of the carbon credits generated
will be dedicated to improving the social and environmental conditions in the project region,
specifically contributing to improving deforestation control, and developing environmental
education and other social activities. The contribution to sustainability is being monitored
through the application of the SOCIALCARBON® Standard and CCB Standard. The
SOCIALCARBON Standard is based on six main indicators: Biodiversity; Natural; Financial;
Human; Social and Carbon Resources and CCB Standard is based on The Climate, Community
and Biodiversity Standards.
The AUD REDD project is expected to avoid predicted deforestation of 4,458.86 ha, which is
equivalent to 1,521,031 tCO2e in emission reductions over the 30-year life of the project
(10/October/2022, to 09/October/2052), with an annual average of 50,701 tCO2e.
The APD REDD project is expected to avoid predicted deforestation of 843 ha, which is equivalent
to 163,451 tCO2e in emissions reductions over the 30 years life of the project, with an annual
average of 5,448 tCO2e.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral Scope: 14 – Agriculture, Forestry, Land Use
Project Category: Avoided Unplanned Deforestation (AUD Project Activity) and Avoided Planned
Deforestation (APD Project Activity).
This is a grouped project.
1.3 Project Eligibility
According to the VCS Methodology Requirements, v48, for Reduced Emissions from Deforestation
and Degradation (REDD) projects, eligible activities are those that reduce net GHG emissions by
reducing deforestation. Thus, the project is eligible under the scopes of the VCS Program,
following the VCS Standard, v49, Sections 3.1, 3.2 and Appendix A1.5 – A1.8:

2 GENERAL
2.1 Project Goals, Design and Long-Term Viability
2.1.1 Summary Description of the Project (G1.2)
Xinjiang Burqin Improved Grassland Management Project Phase II (hereafter as “the project”) is
located in Burqin County, Altai City, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, China. The project is
aimed to restore the local degraded grassland ecosystem from adoption of sustainable grassland
management practices, such as improving the rotation of grazing animals between summer and
winter pastures, limiting the timing and number of grazing animals on degraded pastures, and
ensuring appropriate management over the long-term. The project proponent is Burqin Jinhua
Urban Construction and Investment Co., Ltd.
According to the Parameters for Degradation, Sandification and Salification of Rangelands
(National standard of China, GB19377-2003) and Project Design Report, moderately degraded
areas refer to the total grass yield decreased by 21%-50% compared with that before degradation
and the total grass yield decreased by 50% compared with that before degradation is regarded as
severely degraded grasslands. According to the baseline survey, before the implementation of the
project, the grassland in the project area was facing serious degradation and even desertification
due to the impact of climate change and human activities, most of them were moderately degraded
while some of them even severely degraded for years.
Totally, 68,333.33 ha of degraded grassland has been managed sustainably by rotational and rest
grazing through fence building. And that reduce net GHG emissions by increasing carbon stocks
and/or reducing non-CO GHG emissions. 2
The main restoration measure rest and rotational grazing were implemented in 68,333.33 ha of
degraded grassland where grass yield is about 72.46 Kg/Mu which was decreased by 41.56%
compared with the non-degraded grassland data in 2000. For the first five years, grazing was
strictly forbidden and then, sustainable grassland management methods will be applied, such as
rotational grazing in different pastoral areas, limits the time and number of grazing in the project
area to protect the natural grassland resources, curb the deterioration of the ecological environment
of the natural grassland, It requires that the grazing time shall be halved by dividing grasslands into
seasonal grazing land according to the livestock carrying capacity of the grassland by fence
building. Then based on specified grazing order, grazing cycle and zoning grazing time, the
grassland is grazed area by area and used in turn.
Besides these main restoration measures, the project also alleviates soil desertification and restore
grassland vegetation to improve soil carbon storage and local biodiversity through grassland
management measures, such as daily management measures from other protect projects like
rodent and pest control and grassland fire prevention to ensure the long-term sustainable
management of the project area.
The objectives of the project including:
Climate: Restore the degraded grassland ecosystem, increase grassland coverage, increase
grassland carbon sink function and reduce GHG emissions.

A.4.3. Technology to be employed by the project activity:
Wind resource in the region is considered adequate but not exceptional. According to measurements it has
been determined that the annual average wind speed at the height of 70m is 6.50 m/s. Taking into account
the effects of the frictional drag of the terrain, the average wind speed at the height of hub (55m and 65m) is
6.23 m/s and 6.49 m/s (calculated with the WasP software) and the average wind power density is between
294W/m2 and 325W/m2.
Based on the conditions of wind resource it is therefore proposed to use advanced technology to optimise the
power generation efficiency at lower wind-speeds. The project therefore proposes to make use of IEC III
resource technology that is more efficient at lower wind speeds. Considering the terrain of the wind farm
and the commercialization level of wind turbines internationally, it’s planned to import pitch regulation
turbines with a unit capacity of 850kW or above.

and therefore will generate non-conventional energy certificates. This mechanism, however, is a non-
GHG related environmental mechanism, so there are no double-counting issues involved with the VCS
program in this case. However, in case the VCS standard considers there are double-counting issues
with the ERNC mechanism or any other mechanism the Viñales project might participate in the future, the
Project Proponent will take all the necessary measures and safeguards in order to avoid any double-
counting issues.
1.12.4 Other Forms of Environmental Credit
The Viñales project is not involved to any other form of GHG-related environmental credit for GHG
emission reductions or removals other than the VCS Program.
1.12.5 Projects Rejected by Other GHG Programs
The Viñales project activity failed to obtain registration under the CDM in 2011, as it failed to comply with
some procedural requirements related to additionality; in particular, with issues related to the early
consideration of the CDM. Though the CDM was duly considered by the Project Proponent from the very

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice
cultivation is conducted in Northwest of Leizhou City1 within Zhanjiang City, Guangdong
Province of China, with a total acreage of 6,467 ha for double-cropping rice. Without the
implementation of this project, the continuously flooded method would be continued, so the
scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario.
Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of
methane (CH ) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is 4
more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and methane emission reduction
than the continuously flooded.
This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which results
in not only large amount of methane (CH ) emissions but also low rice productivity by 4
replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method, which shortens
the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. In this case, the CH emission 4
can be declined by an average of 48%2 . Hence, with the proposed project activity, an
estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 9.27 tCO e/ha for double-cropping rice is 2
expected. Annual average estimation of GHG emission reductions from the project activity
is 59,929 tCO e/year, and the total GHG emission reductions are 599,290 tCO e during the 2 2
fixed 10 years crediting period.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes;
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers;
- Increase the number of local individuals who have relevant skills due to diversified
educational opportunities from trainings;
- Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers.

Research Institute. Available from: r.wassmann@irri.org

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Proposed Project
Outline: Through this project activity, Pivot Bio will evaluate the impact of replacing synthetic
nitrogen fertilizer with an in-season nitrogen source that fixes and supplies nitrogen to the roots
corn and other cereal crops. One such source is nitrogen-fixing microbes that convert
atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia, a plant available form of N, supplying N to the plant during
the most critical stages of growth. This treatment offers unique advantages over synthetic
nitrogen fertilizer, including consistency (microbes do not leach or volatilize during weather
events), accessibility (biological nitrogen fixation occurs on the root of the crop, making N
readily available to the plant), and resiliency (microbes produce nitrogen throughout the
growing season, matching N availability to crop needs).
Location: This project will include farms in the U.S. Corn Belt. Please see appendix A for
specific geographies.
GHG Reductions & Removals: Biological nitrogen-fixation for cereal crops is a new
technology, brought to market by Pivot Bio in 2019. These microbes are the first nitrogen
source that can replace synthetic nitrogen fertilizer by fixing and supplying N to cereal crops,
allowing growers within the project boundary to apply less synthetic nitrogen on the field. Lower
applications of synthetic nitrogen fertilizer have the well-documented impact of reducing nitrous
oxide (N O) emissions, and in certain cases, growers may also see a reduction in additional 2
GHG emissions from reduced equipment use. In total, the GHG emission reductions from
reduced synthetic fertilizer use will be used to generate credits.
Current Practice: Prior to the introduction of nitrogen-fixing microbes for cereal crops (and
still the case for farms that have not adopted the technology), synthetic nitrogen fertilizer is
applied to fields with the expectation that half or more of the applied nitrogen will be lost to
weather events. Synthetic nitrogen fertilizer is lost as nitrous oxide both directly from the soil
and indirectly as nitrate leached into waterways, generating GHG emissions. Nitrogen-fixing
microbes supply nitrogen the crop needs without the typical loss of N attributed to bulk
application of synthetic N fertilizer. Growers that use nitrogen-fixing microbes to replace
synthetic N emissions therefore have lower levels of GHG emissions than they would if they did
not use this product.
Estimate of impact: Commercially sensitive information has been excluded from the public
version of this project description & will be provided to VBB.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral Scope 14. This will be a grouped project.
1.3 Project Eligibility

Deforestation and Degradation (REDD) project and has been developed in compliance with the Verified

1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Nam Ngiep 2A Hydropower project (hereafter referred to as “the project”) is developed by Nonghai
Group Sole Company Limited in Sanluang Town, Khoun District, Xieng Khouang Province, Lao
PDR. The primary purpose of the project is to generate electricity to the Lao Power Grid.
Total installed capacity of the project is 10.50 MW, provided by two (2) Horizontal Francis
turbines. The scheduled commissioning date of the project activity is expected to be on 08-
August-2024 with an average annual output of 44,270 MWh.
The project is expected to constantly contribute clean energy to the Lao Power Grid. It not only
conforms to the present situation, but also can adapt to future changes in the electricity market.
The baseline scenario of the project is continuation of the present situation, i.e., electricity
supplied from the power grid. By displacing part of the power generated by thermal power plants,
the project is therefore expected to reduce an average annual emission reduction of 20,550
tCO e per year with a total emission reduction of 143,851 tCO e during the first crediting period. 2 2
The project is not only supplying renewable electricity to grid, but also producing positive
environmental and economic benefits and also, promotes the local sustainable development in
the following aspects:
• During the construction period, plenty of job opportunities were provided to local
residents.
• The infrastructure has been greatly improved. The enhancement of the transportation
and electricity system brings substantial benefits to local villagers.
• The use of fossil fuel will be reduced because of displacement by grid electricity, this
reduces the fossil fuel-based electricity generation.
• Provide clean & cheap electricity in this region, promote the sustainable development
in this region and slowing down the increasing trend of GHG emissions.

United Nations Sustainability Goals
The United Nations and United States have recognized the importance of trees and nature
based solutions to climate change. WT-SEUSS-1 supports Sustainable Development Goals
(SDGs) developed by the United Nations including:
1. A commitment to protect, restore, and promote sustainable use of terrestrial

while also increasing soil fertility and local biodiversity. Increasing water availability and subsoil
nutrients increases land productivity with fewer fertilizers, less water waste and pollution from
runoff, and creates a habitat for animals previously unsupported (Karki et al 2012). Livestock
